page.text: P a g e | i i
This report presents the results of the Transportation Impact Analysis (TIA) prepared for the proposed mixed-use
development at 641 N Capitol Avenue in San Jose, California. The 10.6-acre lot currently has one single-family
home that would be removed with the proposed project. Two driveways off of Gimelli Way would provide access
to the residential and retail uses, a third driveway along Gimelli Way would provide access to the self-storage
warehouse, and one driveway along N Capitol Avenue would provide access to the medical office.
The project is located within the N. Capitol Avenue/McKee Road Urban Village. As part of the Envision San Jose
2040 General Plan, the City has identified historically underutilized locations within San Jose that will be
developed as “Urban Villages.” These urban villages will promote the development of active, walkable, bicycle
friendly, transit-oriented, mixed-use urban settings for new housing and job growth. The general plan provides a
policy framework to direct new housing and employment projects into these urban villages.
This study was conducted for the purpose of identifying potential traffic impacts related to the proposed
development. The impacts of the project were evaluated following the standards and methodologies set forth by
the City of San Jose. Project impacts on other transportation facilities, such as bicycle facilities and transit
services, were determined on the basis of engineering judgment. The study determined the traffic impacts of the
proposed development on seven signalized intersections during the weekday AM and PM peak periods of traffic.
None of the study intersections are CMP-designated intersections.
The proposed project consists of 188 townhomes, a 28,000 square foot (s.f.) medical office, 5,000 s.f. of retail
space, 5,000 s.f. of office space, and a 70,000-s.f. self-storage warehouse. After applying the standard ITE trip
generation rates to the proposed uses, subtracting the existing trip credits, and applying the trip reductions, the
proposed project would generate 2,029 net new daily vehicle trips with 135 new trips occurring during the AM
peak hour and 193 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour. Using the inbound/outbound splits
recommended by ITE, the project would produce 65 new inbound and 69 new outbound trips during the AM peak
hour and 87 new inbound and 106 new outbound trips during the PM peak hour.
This analysis also includes an evaluation of an alternative development option. The project alternative consists of
178 townhomes, 315 apartments, 5,000 s.f. of retail space, 6,000 s.f. of office space, and a 28,000 s.f. medical
office. After applying the standard ITE trip generation rates to the proposed uses, subtracting the existing trip
credits, and applying the trip reductions, the project alternative would generate 3,657 net new daily vehicle trips
with 267 new trips occurring during the AM peak hour and 342 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour.
Using the inbound/outbound splits recommended by ITE, the project alternative would produce 79 new inbound
and 188 new outbound trips during the AM peak hour and 197 new inbound and 145 new outbound trips during
Auto Trip Reduction Statements, as required by the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority (VTA), are
included at the end of the Executive Summary.
The completion of the eastbound side of Gimelli Way should be included as part of the proposed project or the
project alternative. This roadway completion should include appropriate lane widths for two-way traffic, and the
provision of sidewalks along Gimelli Way to meet City standards. Currently, Gimelli Way does not have any
P a g e | i i i
defined lane striping. With the development of this project, Gimelli Way should be striped to include one
westbound receiving lane and two eastbound lanes: one right-turn lane and one shared left-turn/through lane.
The results of the intersection level of service analysis show all of the study intersections would operate at
acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better) during both peak hours under all analysis conditions for both the
proposed project and the project alternative. A summary of the level of service calculations can be seen in Table
ES-1 for the proposed project, and in Table ES-2 for the project alternative.
Hexagon performed a detailed review of the proposed site plan, including site access, on-site circulation, and
parking. Hexagon also analyzed the proposed project with regard to vehicle queuing, and impacts on transit,
pedestrian, and bicycle facilities. The review resulted in the following recommendations.
The project should complete the eastbound side of Gimelli Way, including new sidewalks built to City
standards. The project should provide a 36-foot curb-to-curb width along Gimelli Way. The west leg of the
N Capitol Avenue and Gimelli Way/Rainfield Drive intersection should be striped to include two 18-foot
As part of the development of the crosswalk on the south leg of the N Capitol Avenue and Gimelli
Way/Rainfield Drive intersection, the project should provide accessible pedestrian signals and lead/lag
signal operations, as requested by the City. The project should work with the proper waste collection
agencies (including garbage, recycling, and yard trimmings) to determine the adequacy of waste
collection vehicles to enter and back-out of the dead-end drive aisles on-site.
The project should provide adequate loading zones (one) for the medical office use as required by the
City. This loading zone should be provided within either the parking area surrounding the medical office or
the “Food Truck Alley/Tech-Office Pick-Up” area shown on the site plan.
The project should provide adequate loading zones (three) for the self-storage warehouse as required by
the City. These loading zones should be provided within the self-storage warehouse parking area, access
The proposed project and project alternative should provide adequate bicycle parking facilities to meet
the City’s requirements. Bicycle parking for the townhomes should be provided within each unit’s garage.
The project should ensure each garage has adequate space to park two vehicles and a bicycle. The
project should provide three bike spaces near the retail/office building and six bike spaces near the
The project should provide a detailed project alternative site plan that includes location for and access to
the high-density residential use, and provision of adequate parking to meet City requirements.
The project should ensure no landscaping or other objects are placed near the project driveways that
would adversely affect sight distance for exiting vehicles. This includes adequate no parking zones at
each project driveway along Gimelli Way.
The project should modify the driveway serving the warehouse based on the City of San Jose’s

page.text: This report presents the results of the Transportation Impact Analysis (TIA) prepared for the proposed mixed-use
development at 641 N. Capitol Avenue in San Jose, California (see Figure 1). The proposed project consists of
188 townhomes, a 28,000 square foot (s.f.) medical office, 5,000 s.f. of retail space, 5,000 s.f. of office space,
and a 70,000-s.f. self-storage warehouse. The 11-acre lot currently has one single-family home that would be
removed with the proposed project. Two entrances off of Gimelli Way would provide access to the residential
and retail uses, a third entrance along Gimelli Way would provide access to the self-storage warehouse, and one
driveway along N. Capitol Avenue would provide access to the medical office (see Figure 2).
This analysis also includes an evaluation of an alternative development option. This alternative consists of 178
townhomes, 315 apartments, 5,000 s.f. of retail space, 5,000 s.f. of office space, and a 28,000 s.f. medical office.
This study was conducted for the purpose of identifying the potential traffic impacts related to the proposed
project. The potential impacts of the project were evaluated in accordance with the standards set forth by the
City of San Jose. Since the proposed project is expected to generate more than 100 peak hour vehicle trips, this
traffic analysis follows the Santa Clara County Valley Transportation Agency (VTA) Congestion Management
Program (CMP) guidelines. The traffic analysis is based on the AM and PM peak hour levels of service for five
1. N. Capitol Avenue & McKee Road (San Jose Protected Intersection)
6. N. Capitol Avenue & Rainfield Drive/Gimelli Way
7. N. Capitol Avenue & Penitencia Creek Road
None of the study intersections is part of the CMP roadway network.
The CMP TIA guidelines also require that freeway segments be evaluated to determine the impact of added
traffic for projects that generate trips equal to or greater than one percent of the freeway segment’s capacity. The
project is not expected to add traffic equal to or greater than one percent of the capacity on the I-680 freeway
segments in the project vicinity. Therefore, an analysis of freeway segments was not conducted for this project.
The freeway capacity estimates are included in Appendix E.
Traffic conditions at the study intersections were analyzed for the weekday AM and PM peak hours of adjacent
street traffic. The AM peak hour of adjacent street traffic is generally between 7:00 and 9:00 AM, and the PM
peak hour of adjacent street traffic is typically between 4:00 and 6:00 PM. It is during these periods on an
average weekday that the most congested traffic conditions occur.
Traffic conditions were evaluated for the following scenarios:
Existing Conditions. Existing traffic volumes are based on new traffic counts conducted in
March 2015 and May 2016, while nearby schools were in session.
Existing plus Project and Project Alternative Conditions. Existing traffic volumes with the
project were estimated by adding to existing traffic volumes the traffic generated by the
proposed project and project alternative. Existing plus project conditions were evaluated
relative to existing conditions in order to determine the effects the project would have on the
Background Conditions. Background traffic volumes were estimated by adding to existing
peak-hour volumes the projected volumes from approved but not yet completed developments.
The added traffic from approved but not yet completed developments was provided by the City
of San Jose in the form of the Approved Trips Inventory (ATI).
Background plus Project and Project Alternative Conditions. Projected near-term peak-hour
traffic volumes with the project were estimated by adding to background traffic volumes the
additional traffic generated by the proposed project and project alternative. Background plus
project conditions were evaluated relative to background conditions in order to determine
potential project impacts according to the City of San Jose Level of Service Policy.
Cumulative and Cumulative Alternative Conditions. Traffic volumes under cumulative
conditions were estimated by applying an annual growth factor of 1.2 percent to existing traffic
volumes, and adding trips from approved developments. Proposed project trips and project
alternative trips were added to these volumes to generate cumulative and cumulative
alternative volumes, respectively. Cumulative volumes assume a build-out year of 2019.
This section presents the methods used to determine the traffic conditions for each scenario described above. It
includes descriptions of the data requirements, the analysis methodologies, and the applicable level of service
The data required for the analysis were obtained from new traffic counts, the City of San Jose, and field
observations. The following data were collected from these sources:

i.b: Level of Service Standards and Analysis Methodologies

page.text: Traffic conditions at the study intersections were evaluated using level of service (LOS). Level of Service is a
qualitative description of operating conditions ranging from LOS A, or free-flow conditions with little or no delay,
to LOS F, or jammed conditions with excessive delays. The various analysis methods are described below.

text.b: City of San Jose Signalized Intersections

page.text: The City of San Jose level of service methodology for signalized intersections is the 2000 Highway Capacity
Manual (HCM) method. This method is applied using the TRAFFIX software. The 2000 HCM operations method
evaluates signalized intersection operations on the basis of average control delay time for all vehicles at the
intersection. Since TRAFFIX is also the CMP-designated intersection level-of-service methodology, the City of
San Jose methodology employs the CMP default values for the analysis parameters. The City of San Jose level-
of-service standard for signalized intersections is LOS D or better. The correlation between average control
delay and level of service is shown in Table 1.

text.b: Signalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions Based on Control Delay
City of San Jose Protected Intersections

page.text: The City of San José has identified certain local intersections for which no further vehicle capacity improvements
are planned. These intersections are built to their maximum capacity, where further expansion would cause
significant adverse effects upon existing or approved transit or other multimodal facilities, nearby land uses, or
local neighborhoods. Future infill development that is otherwise consistent with other General Plan policies
encouraging Smart Growth may, therefore, generate additional traffic through these intersections, resulting in a
level of congestion that would not otherwise be consistent with the rest of the City Transportation Impact Policy.
The study intersection of N Capitol Avenue and McKee Road is designated as a San Jose Protected
For selected high-demand movements at key intersections, the estimated maximum vehicle queues were
compared to the existing or planned storage capacity. The queuing analysis is presented for informational
purposes only, since neither the City of San Jose nor the CMP have defined any policies related to queuing.
Vehicle queues were calculated using a Poisson probability distribution, which estimates the probability of “n”
vehicles for a vehicle movement using the following formula:
= n) = probability of “n” vehicles in queue per lane
= number of vehicles in the queue per lane
λ = Average number of vehicles in the queue per lane (vehicles per hour per lane/signal cycles per hour)
The basis of the analysis is as follows: (1) the Poisson probability distribution is used to estimate the 95
percentile maximum number of queued vehicles per signal cycle for a particular movement; (2) the estimated
maximum number of vehicles in the queue is translated into a queue length, assuming 25 feet per vehicle; and
(3) the estimated maximum queue length is compared to the existing or planned available storage capacity for
The project is located within the N. Capitol Avenue/McKee Road Urban Village. As part of the Envision San Jose
2040 General Plan, the City has identified historically underutilized locations within San Jose that will be
developed as “Urban Villages.” These urban villages will promote the development of active, walkable, bicycle
friendly, transit-oriented, mixed-use urban settings for new housing and job growth. The general plan provides a
policy framework to direct new housing and employment projects into these urban villages. The N. Capitol
Avenue/McKee Road Urban Villages anticipates growth of 75,000 s.f. of planned non-residential space, 250
planned jobs, and 700 planned units of housing.
The Circulation Element of the Envision San Jose 2040 General Plan includes a set of balanced, long-range,
multi modal transportation goals and policies that provide for a transportation network that is safe, efficient and
sustainable (minimizes environmental, financial, and neighborhood impacts). These transportation goals and
policies are intended to improve multi-modal accessibility to all land uses and create a city where people are less
reliant on driving to meet their daily needs. San Jose’s Transportation Goals, Policies and Actions aim to:
Establish circulation policies that increase bicycle, pedestrian and transit travel while reducing motor
vehicle trips to increase the City’s share of travel by alternative transportation modes.
Promote San Jose as a walking and bicycling-first city by providing and prioritizing funding for projects
that enhance and improve bicycle and pedestrian facilities.
This report has a total of eight chapters. Chapter 2 describes existing conditions including the existing roadway
network, transit service, bicycle and pedestrian facilities. Chapter 3 presents existing plus project conditions
including descriptions of the method used to estimate project traffic. Chapter 4 presents background conditions.
Chapter 5 presents background plus project conditions, including its impact on the transportation system, and
any recommended mitigation measures. Chapter 6 presents the cumulative conditions and describes the
project’s impact on the cumulative transportation system. Chapter 7 provides an evaluation of other
transportation-related issues, such as site access, on-site circulation, vehicle queuing, parking, as well as
potential project impacts on bicycle, pedestrian, and transit facilities. Chapter 8 presents the study conclusions
including a summary of recommended improvements.
This chapter describes the existing conditions for all of the major transportation facilities near the site, including
the roadway network, transit service, and bicycle and pedestrian facilities. Also included are the existing levels of
service of the key intersections in the study area.
Regional access to the project site is provided by I-680 and major arterials including N. Capitol Avenue and
McKee Avenue. Local access to the site is provided by N. Jackson Avenue, Alum Rock Avenue, Mabury Road,
Berryessa Road, and Gimelli Way. These roadways are described below. Under the City of San Jose General
Plan 2040, N. Capitol Avenue and Alum Rock Avenue are designated as roadways that serve as primary transit
corridors, giving priority to transit modes over automobiles, trucks, and bicycles. N. Jackson Avenue, McKee
Road, Mabury Road, and Berryessa Road are all designated as roadways that serve automobiles, bicycles,
pedestrians, and trucks equally, with incidental transit provisions. N. Capitol Avenue is designated as a major
through-route for bicycles. In general, these designations indicate the City’s intent to alter the existing roadway
cross sections to add bicycle lanes where they are currently missing.
I-680 is a north/south freeway that extends from the US 101/I-280 interchange in San Jose north through Santa
Clara, Alameda, Contra Costa, and Solano Counties to Fairfield where it terminates at I-80. In the vicinity of the
project site, I-680 is eight lanes wide (four mixed-flow in each direction). I-680 provides site access via
interchanges with Berryessa Road and McKee Road.
N. Capitol Avenue is designated as a Grand Boulevard and On-Street Primary Bicycle Facility under the 2040
General Plan. Capitol Avenue runs from Montague Expressway in the north, as an extension of Tasman
Avenue/Great Mall Parkway, to Capitol Expressway in the south. Within the study area, N. Capitol Avenue is a
four-lane arterial with light rail in the median. N. Capitol Avenue provides sidewalks on both sides throughout the
study area and continuous dedicated bike lanes. The signalized Capitol/Gimelli/Rainfield intersection, which is
adjacent to the project site, provides crosswalks with pedestrian signal heads on all but the south approach. The
proposed project would have one driveway on N. Capitol Avenue that would provide access to and from the
McKee Road is designated as a City Connector under the 2040 General Plan. McKee Road runs from US-101 in
the west, as a continuation of E. Julian Street, to Alum Rock Avenue in the east. Within the study area, McKee
Road is a six-lane arterial with an interchange with I-680. McKee Road provides sidewalks on both sides with
pedestrian signal heads at all signalized intersections. Bicycle lanes are not provided, and VTA advises extreme
caution to cyclists on McKee Road.
N. Jackson Avenue is designated as a City Connector under the 2040 General Plan. Jackson Avenue runs from
Berryessa Road in the north, as a continuation of Flickinger Avenue, to Story Road in the south. Within the study
area, N. Jackson Avenue is a four-lane arterial with dedicated bicycle lanes along most of its length. N. Jackson
Avenue provides sidewalks on both sides with pedestrian signal heads at all signalized intersections.
Alum Rock Avenue is designated as a Grand Boulevard under the 2040 General Plan. Alum Rock runs from
US101 in the west, as an extension of E. Santa Clara Street, to Alum Rock Park in the east. Within the study
area, Alum Rock Avenue is a four-lane arterial with an interchange with I-680. Alum Rock Avenue provides
sidewalks and crosswalks on both sides with pedestrian signal heads at all signalized intersections. Bicycle
lanes are not provided, and VTA advises caution to cyclists on Alum Rock Avenue.
Mabury Road is designated as a City Connector under the 2040 General Plan. Mabury Road runs from Oakland
Road in the west to Gridley Road in the east, where it changes designation to San Marino Road. Within the study
area, Mabury Road is a two- to four-lane collector with dedicated bicycle lanes along much of its length. Mabury
Road provides sidewalks on both sides with pedestrian signal heads at all signalized intersections.
Berryessa Road is designated as a City Connector under the 2040 General Plan. Berryessa Road runs from
Mabury Road (frontage to US 101) in the west to Piedmont Avenue in the east, where it changes designation to
Suncrest Avenue. Within the study area, Berryessa Road is a four-lane arterial with bicycle lanes. Berryessa
Road provides sidewalks on both sides with pedestrian signal heads at all signalized intersections.
Gimelli Way is a local road that extends east from Easton Drive to its terminus at N Capitol Avenue. Gimelli Way
is currently a partially developed, unstriped two-lane road with curbs and sidewalks along its northern
(westbound) edge. The roadway would be completed with the proposed project and provide access to the project
Within the project study area, on-street bike lanes (Class II bikeways) are located along Capitol Avenue, Capitol
Expressway, Berryessa Road, Maybury Road, N. Jackson Avenue and E. San Antonio Street (see Figure 3).
Furthermore, the Penitencia Creek Trail, a Class I bike path, is located approximately three-fourths of a mile
north of the project site. Connecting roadways, including McKee Road and Alum Rock Avenue, do not include
designated on-street bicycle facilities and are only recommended for use by confident and experienced cyclists.
Although not designated as bicycle routes, several other local roadway segments including Gimelli Way have
relatively low traffic volumes and low speeds and are thus suitable for bicyclists.
Pedestrian facilities in the study area consist of sidewalks along all surrounding local roadways. There is
currently no sidewalk along the project frontage on Gimelli Way. Most intersections within the study area are
signalized, and all of these provide crosswalks and pedestrian signal heads.
Existing transit services to the study area are provided by the VTA. The transit services are described below and
Local Route 22/Limited Route 522 provides bus service from the Palo Alto Transit Center to the
Eastridge Transit Center. It operates primarily along El Camino Real/The Alameda/Santa Clara
Street/Alum Rock Avenue and Capitol Avenue/Capitol Expressway with connections to Caltrain, light rail,
Amtrak, and numerous local and express buses operated by VTA and neighboring transit agencies.
Route 22 operates 24 hours a day, with 15-minute headways for most of the day every day. Route 522
operates weekdays from 5:30 AM to 11:30 PM eastbound and 4:30 AM to 11:00 PM westbound, with 15-
minute headway during peak commute and daytime hours. Weekend service operates with longer
headways, with more limited hours for Route 522.
Community Bus Route 45 provides bus service from the Alum Rock Transit Center to the Penitencia
Creek Transit Center. It operates primarily on White Road, Penitencia Creek Road, Toyon Avenue, and
Alum Rock Avenue, with connections to light rail, Express Route 104, and other local bus routes. Route
45 operates weekdays from 6:30 AM to 7:00 PM northbound and 6:30 AM to 6:30 PM southbound, with
Local Route 61 provides bus service from Good Samaritan Hospital to Sierra Road and Piedmont Road
via Bascom Avenue. It operates primarily on Bascom Avenue, Naglee Avenue/Taylor Street/Mabury
Road with connections to light rail, express bus routes, and numerous local bus routes. Route 61
operates weekdays from 6:00 AM to 10:30 PM northbound and 5:45 AM to 10:15 PM southbound, with
30-minute headways throughout the day. Weekend service operates with 60-minute headways and more
Local Route 62 provides bus service from Good Samaritan Hospital to Sierra Road and Piedmont Road
via Union Avenue. It operates primarily on Union Avenue, Bascom Avenue, Naglee Avenue/Taylor
Street, and Hedding Street/Berryessa Road with connections to light rail, express bus routes, and
numerous local bus routes. Route 62 operates weekdays from 6:00 AM to 11:00 PM northbound and
5:30 AM to 10:45 PM southbound, with 30-minute headways during peak commute and daytime hours.
Weekend service operates with 60-minute headways and more limited hours.
Local Route 64 provides bus service from the Almaden Light Rail Station to McKee Road and White
Road via Downtown. It operates primarily on Almaden Expressway, San Fernando Street, and Julian
Street/McKee Road with connections to Caltrain, Light Rail, Amtrak, and numerous local and express
buses operated by VTA and neighboring transit agencies. Route 64 operates weekdays from 5:30 AM to
11:30 PM northbound and 5:30 AM to 11:00 PM southbound, with 15- to 30-minute headways during
peak commute hours. More frequent trips operate in both directions between San Jose Diridon Station
and McKee Road and White Road. Weekend service operates with 30-minute headways and more
Local Route 70 provides bus service from the Capitol Light Rail Station to the Great Mall/Main Transit
Center. It operates primarily on Capitol Expressway, Jackson Avenue/Flickinger Avenue, and Montague
Expressway/Landess Avenue with connections to light rail and numerous local bus routes. Route 70
operates weekdays from 5:30 AM to 11:30 PM northbound and 5:15 AM to 11:00 PM southbound, with
20-minute headways during peak commute hours. Weekend service operates with 30-minute headways
Express Route 104 provides bus service from the Penitencia Creek Transit Center to Palo Alto. It
operates primarily on US 101 between San Jose/Milpitas and Palo Alto, with connections to light rail and
numerous local bus routes. Route 104 operates on weekdays only with two morning westbound trips and
two afternoon eastbound trips during peak commute hours.
Within the study area, there are stops for all above bus and light rail lines within approximately one mile of the
project site. All stops can be reached via sidewalks and crosswalks at signalized intersections. However, all bus
stops are more than 0.25 miles walking distance from the project site, which is the typical upper limit of
Routes 45 and 61 have stops at N. Capitol Avenue and Mabury Road, 0.4 miles from the project site.
Route 64 has a stop at N. Capitol Avenue and McKee Road, 0.5 miles from the project site.
Routes 45, 61, and 104 stop at the Penitencia Creek Transit Center, 0.5 miles from the project site.
Route 70 has a stop at N. Jackson Avenue and Mabury Road, 0.9 miles from the project site.
Routes 22 and 522 have stops at Capitol Avenue and Alum Rock Avenue, 1.1 miles from the project
The Santa Teresa to Alum Rock light rail line (Route 901) provides local and express rail service between Santa
Teresa in South San Jose and the Eastridge Transit Center in East San Jose via Downtown, North First Street,
Tasman Drive, and Capitol Avenue/Capitol Expressway. It runs weekdays nearly 24 hours, with 15-minute
headways during peak commute and daytime hours. A limited number of express trains run during peak
commute hours in the peak direction. Weekend service begins approximately 1 hour later with similar headways.
The McKee Light Rail station is located 0.2 miles south of the project site on N. Capitol Avenue, with good
pedestrian access via signalized intersections. The Penitencia Creek Light Rail station and transit center is
located 0.6 miles north on N. Capitol Avenue. Both stations are served by the Santa Teresa to Alum Rock light

text.b: Existing Intersection Lane Configurations and Traffic Volumes

page.text: The existing lane configurations at the study intersections were obtained by observations in the field and through
Google Earth (see Figure 5). Existing traffic volumes were obtained from new traffic counts conducted in May
2016 and March 2015, while schools were in session (see Figure 6). The traffic count data are included in
Intersection levels of service were evaluated against the City of San Jose standards (see Table 2). The level of
service results show that all study intersections are operating at an acceptable LOS D or better under existing
conditions. The level of service calculations are included in Appendix C.

text.b: Existing Intersection Levels of Service Summary

page.text: N Capitol Ave & Rainfield Dr/Gimelli Way
N Capitol Ave & Penitencia Creek Rd
Traffic conditions in the field were observed in order to identify existing operational deficiencies and to confirm
the accuracy of calculated intersection levels of service. The purpose of this effort was (1) to identify any existing
traffic problems that may not be directly related to level of service, and (2) to identify any locations where the
level of service analysis does not accurately reflect existing traffic conditions.
In the AM peak period, existing operational issues occurred in the northbound direction at the intersection of N.
Capitol Avenue and Berryessa Road. During this peak period, the northbound left turn from N. Capitol Avenue
onto Berryessa Road was observed to exceed the left-turn storage. In the northbound direction there are two left-
turn only lanes, however it was noticed that vehicles primarily use the right-most turn lane in order to access the
I-680 northbound on-ramp. This right-most turn lane was observed filling up before the left-most turn lane filled
up, preventing vehicles from accessing the other lane. The protected left-turn green time was long enough that
all vehicles, including those queued up past the storage pocket, were able to clear the intersection in a single
cycle. Beyond this issue regarding the northbound left turn, there were no observed operational issues at this
The remainder of the study intersections exhibited no significant operational issues and operated at LOS D or
better. Based on the above discussion, we determined that the calculated level-of-service results reflect actual
traffic conditions observed in the field.
During the PM peak period operational issues were observed at the intersections of N. Capitol Avenue and
McKee Road, and at N. Capitol Avenue and Mabury Road. The eastbound left-turns at the intersection of N.
Capitol Avenue and McKee Road were observed spilling out of the storage pocket by eight vehicles. A large
majority of the traffic in this direction turned left, and so this spill back did not cause any issues for the other
movements. Not all of the left-turning vehicles cleared the intersection in a single cycle. In the northbound
direction at the intersection of N. Capitol Avenue and Mabury Road, the left-turn volume was significantly higher
than the other movements. The turning vehicles came close to exceeding the left-turn storage, but all were able
to clear the intersection in one cycle. The eastbound through queues at this intersection were long enough that
they prevented vehicles from entering the left- and right-turn lanes. Despite this, all vehicles queued in this
direction were able to clear the intersection in a single cycle.
The remained of the study intersections exhibited no significant operational issues and operated at LOS D or
better. Based on the above discussion, we determined that the calculated level of service results reflect actual
traffic conditions observed in the field.
This chapter describes existing plus project traffic conditions, including the method by which project traffic is
estimated. Existing plus project traffic conditions could potentially occur if the project were to be occupied prior to
the other approved projects in the area. It is unlikely that this traffic condition would occur, since other approved
projects expected to add traffic to the study area would likely be built and occupied during the time the project is
going through the development review process.
The magnitude of traffic produced by a new development and the locations where that traffic would appear are
estimated using a three-step process: 1) trip generation, 2) trip distribution, and 3) trip assignment. In
determining project trip generation, the magnitude of traffic entering and exiting the site is estimated for the AM
and PM peak hours. As part of the project trip distribution, an estimate is made of the directions to and from
which the project trips would travel. In the project trip assignment, the project trips are assigned to specific
streets and intersections. These procedures are described below.
Through empirical research, data have been collected that quantify the amount of traffic produced by common
land uses. Thus, for the most common land uses there are standard trip generation rates that can be applied to
help predict the future traffic increases that would result from a new development. The magnitude of traffic added
to the roadway system by a particular development is estimated by multiplying the applicable trip generation
rates by the size of the development. Trip generation resulting from new development proposed within the City of
San Jose typically is estimated using the trip rates published in the Institute of Transportation Engineers’ (ITE)
Trips that are generated by existing occupied uses can be subtracted from the gross project trip generation
estimates. Accordingly, trip credits were applied to account for the single-family home that would be removed as
part of the project. ITE trip generation rates for single-family homes were used for this purpose.
A mixed-used development with complementary land uses such as residential and retail would generate and
attract trips internally between the uses. Thus, the number of vehicle trips generated for each use may be
reduced, since a portion of the trips would not require entering or exiting the site. The VTA’s Congestion
Management Program Transportation Impact Analysis Guidelines (March 2009) indicates a trip reduction of up to
15 percent is allowed for residential and retail mixed-use developments, and residential and office mixed-use
developments. The reduction is applied to the smaller of the two complimentary trip generators, and the same
number of trips is then subtracted from the larger trip generator to account for both trip ends. The proposed
project includes numerous mixed-use elements that would reduce trips between the residential development and
the other uses. The mixed-use reduction was applied to the residential use and then subtracted proportionately
from each of the remaining three complimentary uses (office, retail, and warehouse). Similarly, the project
alternative includes numerous mixed-use elements. For the alternative, the mixed-use reduction was applied to
each of the three complimentary land uses (office, retail, and warehouse) and then subtracted from the
Since the project site is located within a 2,000-foot walk of an LRT station (McKee Station), the number of trips
generated by the residential and office components of the project were reduced by 9 percent and 6 percent,
respectively. These standard reductions are contained in the VTA TIA Guidelines (October 2014).
A retail pass-by trip reduction of 15 percent can be applied to the net peak hour trip generation estimates for the
proposed retail space. Pass-by-trips are trips that would already be on the adjacent roadways but would turn into
the site while passing by. Justification for applying the pass-by-trip reduction is founded on the observation that
such retail traffic is not actually generated by the retail development, but is already part of the ambient traffic
After applying the standard ITE trip generation rates to the proposed uses, subtracting the existing trip credits,
and applying the trip reductions, the proposed project would generate 2,029 net new daily vehicle trips with 135
new trips occurring during the AM peak hour and 193 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour (see Table 3).
Using the inbound/outbound splits recommended by ITE, the project would produce 65 new inbound and 69 new
outbound trips during the AM peak hour and 87 new inbound and 106 new outbound trips during the PM peak
After applying the standard ITE trip generation rates to the proposed uses, subtracting the existing trip credits,
and applying the trip reductions, the project alternative would generate 3,657 net new daily vehicle trips with 267
new trips occurring during the AM peak hour and 342 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour (see Table 4).
Using the inbound/outbound splits recommended by ITE, the project alternative would produce 79 new inbound
and 188 new outbound trips during the AM peak hour and 197 new inbound and 145 new outbound trips during
The trip distribution pattern for this project was estimated based on existing travel patterns on the surrounding
roadway system and the locations of complimentary land uses (see Figure 7).
The peak-hour vehicle trips generated by the project were assigned to the roadway network in accordance with
the trip distribution patterns (see Figures 8 and 9).
Existing plus project peak hour traffic volumes were estimated by adding to existing traffic volumes the additional
traffic generated by the project. The existing plus project traffic volumes are shown graphically on Figure 10. The
existing plus project alternative traffic volumes are shown graphically on Figure 11.

text.b: Existing Plus Project Intersection Levels of Service

page.text: The results show that all intersections would continue to operate at acceptable levels of service compared
against the City of San Jose standards (see Table 5). No intersections would have a degradation in level of
service between the existing and existing plus project or existing plus project alternative scenarios. Intersection
level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix C.

text.b: Existing plus Project Intersection Levels of Service Summary

page.text: N Capitol Ave & Rainfield Dr/Gimelli Way
N Capitol Ave & Penitencia Creek Rd
This chapter presents background traffic conditions, which are defined as conditions just prior to completion of
the proposed project. Traffic volumes for background conditions comprise volumes from existing traffic counts
plus traffic generated by other approved developments in the vicinity of the site. This chapter describes the
procedure used to determine background traffic volumes and the resulting traffic conditions. The background
scenario predicts a realistic traffic condition that would occur as approved developments are built and occupied.
It was assumed in this analysis that the transportation network under background conditions would be the same
Background peak-hour traffic volumes were estimated by adding to existing peak-hour volumes the estimated
traffic from approved but not yet constructed developments (see Figure 12). The added traffic from approved but
not yet constructed developments in the City of San Jose was obtained from the City’s Approved Trips Inventory
(ATI). The ATI is contained in Appendix B.

text.b: Intersection Levels of Service Under Background Conditions

page.text: The results of the intersection level of service analysis under background conditions show that all of the study
intersections would operate at an acceptable level of service during both the AM and PM peak hours (see Table
6) The intersection level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix C.
N Capitol Ave & Rainfield Dr/Gimelli Way
N Capitol Ave & Penitencia Creek Rd
This chapter describes near-term traffic conditions that most likely would occur when the project is complete. It
includes a description of the City of San Jose significance criteria used to establish what constitutes a project
impact, the method by which project traffic is estimated, and any impacts caused by the project. Background plus
project conditions were evaluated relative to background conditions in order to determine potential project
impacts. This traffic scenario represents a more congested traffic condition than the existing plus project
scenario, since it includes traffic generated by approved but not yet built projects in the area.
Significance criteria are used to establish what constitutes an impact. For this analysis, the criteria used to
determine significant impacts on signalized intersections are based on City of San Jose level-of-service
standards. The effects of the project on other transportation facilities, such as bicycle facilities and transit
service, were determined on the basis of engineering judgment.

i.b: City of San Jose Definition of Significant Intersection Impacts

page.text: The project is said to create a significant adverse impact on traffic conditions at a signalized intersection in the
City of San Jose if for either peak hour:
1. The level of service at the intersection degrades from an acceptable LOS D or better under background
conditions to an unacceptable LOS E or F under background plus project conditions, or
2. The level of service at the intersection is an unacceptable LOS E or F under background conditions and
the addition of project trips causes both the critical-movement delay at the intersection to increase by
four or more seconds and the volume-to-capacity ratio (V/C) to increase by one percent (.01) or more, or
An exception to rule #2 above applies when the addition of project traffic reduces the amount of average delay
for critical movements (i.e. the change in average stopped delay for critical movements is negative). In this case,
the threshold of significance is an increase in the critical V/C value by .01 or more.
A significant impact by City of San Jose standards is said to be satisfactorily mitigated when the measures are
implemented that would restore intersection level-of-service to background conditions or better.
If a development has a significant traffic impact at a designated Protected Intersection, the project may be
approved if offsetting Transportation System Improvements are provided. The offsetting improvements are
intended to provide other transportation benefits for the community adjacent to the traffic impact. The
improvements may include enhancements to pedestrian, bicycle, and transit facilities, as well as neighborhood
traffic calming measures and other roadway improvements.

text.b: Transportation Network Under Background Plus Project Conditions

page.text: It is assumed in this analysis that the transportation network under background plus project conditions would be
the same as the existing transportation network.
As previous described in Chapter 3, the proposed project would generate 2,029 net new daily vehicle trips with
135 new trips occurring during the AM peak hour and 193 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour (see
Table 3). Using the inbound/outbound splits recommended by ITE, the project would produce 65 new inbound
and 69 new outbound trips during the AM peak hour and 87 new inbound and 106 new outbound trips during the
The project alternative would generate 3,657 net new daily vehicle trips with 267 new trips occurring during the
AM peak hour and 342 new trips occurring during the PM peak hour (see Table 4). Using the inbound/outbound
splits recommended by ITE, the project alternative would produce 79 new inbound and 188 new outbound trips
during the AM peak hour and 197 new inbound and 145 new outbound trips during the PM peak hour.
The peak-hour trips generated by the project and project alternative were added to background traffic volumes to
obtain background plus project and background plus project alternative traffic volumes, respectively (see Figures
13 and 14). The project trips were assigned to the roadway system in accordance with the trip distribution
patterns discussed in Chapter 3. Traffic volumes for all components of traffic are tabulated in Appendix D.

text.b: Intersection LOS Under Background Plus Project Conditions

page.text: The results of the intersection level of service analysis show that under background plus project conditions all of
the study intersections would operate at an acceptable level of service during both the AM and PM peak hours
(see Table 7). In some cases, the addition of project trips results in a reduction in the critical delay at an
intersection. Level of service calculations are weighted such that if a project adds trips to movements operating
with better-than-average delays, the resulting average delay or average critical delay can be reduced. The
intersection level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix C.

text.b: Background Plus Project Intersection Levels of Service

page.text: N Capitol Ave & Rainfield Dr/Gimelli Way
N Capitol Ave & Penitencia Creek Rd
This chapter presents a summary of the traffic conditions that would occur under cumulative conditions.
Cumulative conditions represent the future scenario that includes the planned developments, the proposed
project, and general future traffic growth that may occur by the year 2019, when the project is expected to be
built and fully occupied. A significant cumulative traffic impact is identified by comparing the cumulative traffic
conditions against background conditions. This cumulative traffic scenario is evaluated in order to fulfill CMP and
It is assumed in this analysis that the transportation network under cumulative conditions would be the same as
described under background plus project conditions.
Cumulative conditions reflect traffic conditions in the year 2019 upon full buildout and occupancy of the proposed
project. Following typical City of San Jose procedures, the cumulative no project traffic volumes were estimated
by applying an annual growth factor of 1.2 percent to the existing volumes. Following the application of the
growth factor, approved San Jose trips from the City’s ATI and project generated trips were added to each of the
study intersections to generate the cumulative and cumulative alternative traffic volumes (see Figures 15 and
A significant cumulative traffic impact at an intersection is identified by comparing cumulative traffic conditions
against background traffic conditions. The cumulative growth would create a significant adverse impact on traffic
conditions at a signalized intersection in the City of San Jose if during either the AM or PM peak hour:
1. The level of service at the intersection degrades from an acceptable LOS D or better under background
conditions to an unacceptable LOS E or F under cumulative conditions, or
2. The level of service at the intersection is an unacceptable LOS E or F under background conditions and
the addition of cumulative project trips causes both the critical-movement delay at the intersection to
increase by four or more seconds and the volume-to-capacity ratio (V/C) to increase by 0.01 or more.
An exception to rule #2 above applies when the addition of cumulative project traffic reduces the amount of
average delay for critical movements (i.e., change in average critical delay is negative). In this case, the
threshold of significance is an increase in the critical V/C value by 0.01 or more.
A single project’s contribution to a cumulative intersection impact is deemed considerable in the City of San Jose
if the proportion of project traffic represents 25 percent or more of the increase in total volume from background
traffic conditions to cumulative traffic conditions.

text.b: Cumulative Intersection Level of Service Analysis

page.text: The results of the intersection level of service analysis under cumulative conditions show that all of the
intersections would operate at an acceptable level of service during both peak hours (see Table 8). The
intersection level of service calculation sheets are included in Appendix C.

N Capitol Ave & Penitencia Creek Rd
